algorithm: A step-by-step procedure for solving a problem or completing a task using a computer.
api: Application Programming Interface; a set of rules and protocols for building software applications.
array: A collection of elements of the same type stored in contiguous memory locations.
bandwidth: The maximum rate of data transfer across a given path.
binary: A number system that uses only two digits, 0 and 1.
blockchain: A distributed ledger technology that records transactions across multiple computers.
bool: A data type that can hold only two values: true or false.
bootstrap: The process of loading a program or system that enables itself to execute.
bug: An error or flaw in a software program that causes incorrect behavior.
cache: A hardware or software component that stores data for faster future access.
cloud: Internet-based computing services including storage, processing, and applications.
compiler: A program that converts source code written in a programming language into executable code.
cpu: Central Processing Unit; the primary component that executes instructions in a computer.
cuda: A parallel computing platform and application programming interface by NVIDIA.
database: An organized collection of structured data stored and accessed electronically.
debug: The process of identifying and removing errors from software code.
deployment: The process of releasing and implementing software into a production environment.
docker: A containerization platform that packages applications and their dependencies.
encryption: The process of converting information into code to prevent unauthorized access.
framework: A reusable set of libraries and tools for building applications more efficiently.
frontend: The user-facing part of a software application or website.
function: A reusable block of code that performs a specific task.
git: A distributed version control system for tracking changes in source code.
gpu: Graphics Processing Unit; a specialized processor for parallel processing tasks.
gui: Graphical User Interface; a visual way for users to interact with a computer.
hash: A function that converts input data into a fixed-size string of characters.
heap: A region of memory used for dynamic allocation of data structures.
html: HyperText Markup Language; the standard markup language for creating web pages.
http: HyperText Transfer Protocol; the protocol for transmitting data over the internet.
ide: Integrated Development Environment; a software tool for writing and testing code.
inheritance: A mechanism in object-oriented programming where a class inherits from another class.
ip: Internet Protocol; a set of rules for routing and addressing packets on the internet.
javascript: A versatile programming language primarily used for web development.
json: JavaScript Object Notation; a lightweight format for data interchange.
kernel: The core component of an operating system that manages system resources.
lambda: An anonymous function or function without a name, often used in functional programming.
latency: The delay between a request and a response in a system.
library: A collection of pre-written code and functions that can be reused.
linux: A free and open-source operating system kernel.
loop: A control structure that repeats a block of code multiple times.
machine learning: A subset of artificial intelligence that enables systems to learn from data.
memory: Hardware that stores data and instructions for the CPU to access.
middleware: Software that connects different applications or components in a system.
node: A point in a network or a single computer in a distributed system.
npm: Node Package Manager; a package manager for JavaScript and Node.js.
null: A value indicating the absence of any object or data.
object: An instance of a class that contains data and methods.
optimization: The process of improving code efficiency and performance.
packet: A unit of data transmitted over a network.
palindrome: A word, phrase, or sequence that reads the same forwards and backwards.
parser: A program that analyzes and interprets code or data format.
permission: Access rights assigned to users or processes for files and resources.
pointer: A variable that stores the memory address of another variable.
polymorphism: The ability of objects to take on multiple forms in object-oriented programming.
protocol: A set of rules governing the exchange of data over a network.
python: A high-level, general-purpose programming language known for readability.
queue: A data structure that follows the First-In-First-Out principle.
recursion: A programming technique where a function calls itself to solve a problem.
regex: Regular Expression; a pattern used for searching and matching strings.
repository: A central location where code, documentation, and files are stored.
request: A message sent from a client to a server to perform an action.
response: A message sent from a server back to a client.
rest: Representational State Transfer; an architectural style for web services.
runtime: The period during which a program is executing.
script: A sequence of commands written in a programming language that executes in order.
server: A computer that provides data, services, or functionality to other computers.
socket: An endpoint for network communication between two machines.
sql: Structured Query Language; a language for managing databases.
stack: A data structure that follows the Last-In-First-Out principle.
string: A sequence of characters used to represent text in programming.
struct: A composite data type that groups related variables together.
syntax: The set of rules that defines valid statements in a programming language.
terminal: A command-line interface for interacting with a computer system.
thread: A lightweight unit of execution within a process.
token: A piece of information that represents something of interest.
typescript: A superset of JavaScript that adds static typing capabilities.
udp: User Datagram Protocol; a connectionless internet communication protocol.
ui: User Interface; the visual and interactive elements of a software application.
variable: A named storage location that holds a value which can change.
vector: An array-like data structure that can dynamically resize.
version control: A system that tracks and manages changes to code over time.
virtual: Something that exists or is perceived to exist, but is not physical.
virtualenv: A tool for creating isolated Python environments.
vm: Virtual Machine; a software emulation of a physical computer.
webpack: A module bundler for JavaScript applications.
xml: Extensible Markup Language; a markup language for storing structured data.
authentication: The process of verifying the identity of a user or system.
authorization: The process of granting or denying access to resources after authentication.
backend: The server-side part of an application that handles logic, databases, and APIs.
bit: The smallest unit of data in computing, represented as 0 or 1.
byte: A unit of digital information consisting of 8 bits.
cdn: Content Delivery Network; a distributed network of servers that delivers content faster to users.
cybersecurity: The practice of protecting systems, networks, and data from digital attacks.
devops: A set of practices that combines software development and IT operations.
firmware: Permanent software programmed into hardware devices.
firewall: A security system that monitors and controls incoming and outgoing network traffic.
open source: Software whose source code is freely available for modification and distribution.
scalability: The ability of a system to handle increasing amounts of work or users.
testing: The process of evaluating software to ensure it works as expected.
url: Uniform Resource Locator; the address used to access resources on the internet.
